questions.question: Question 1: Mutation in which of the following genes causes Wilson's disease?
questions.explanation:
Wilson's disease is caused due to a loss-of-function mutation in the ATP7B gene. It an autosomal 
recessive condition. The ATP7B gene is located on chromosome 13q. The gene encodes a copper transporting ATPase 
(ATP7B) which has 2 functions: • Maintains copper in bound form by binding copper to apoceruloplasmin • Helps excrete free copper in bile. 943 
Sold by @itachibot The resulting ATP7B deficiency leads to reduced bound copper and impaired free copper 
excretion. This causes excess deposition of free copper in the tissues, particularly in the liver, 
brain and eye. Menkes disease is an X-linked recessive condition leading to impaired absorption of copper and 
subsequent copper deficiency. Here, the mutation is in the ATP7A gene.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 35-year-old man with tremors and chronic hepatitis is found to have the following 
ophthalmic finding. This patient is also likely to have which of the following?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows the Kayser-Fleischer ring. This,along with the background of hepatitis and 
neuropsychiatric features is characteristic of Wilson's disease. The patient is thus likely to have 
basal ganglia atrophy. In the majority of cases, neuropsychiatric manifestations follow hepatic manifestations. It is due 
to the deposition of free copper in the basal ganglia and cortex. Free copper deposition in the 
basal ganglia leads to bilateral degeneration and atrophy.

questions.question:
Question 3: 936 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following would you use to screen an asymptomatic sibling of a patient with 
Wilson's disease?
questions.explanation:
Genetic testing for the ATP7B gene is used to screen asymptomatic 1st and 2nd-degree relatives of 
patients with Wilson's disease. This helps to differentiate the heterozygous from the homozygous 
individuals. This can be useful in the early initiation of treatment before the onset of symptoms. Low serum ceruloplasmin, raised 24 hr urinary copper and Kayser-Fleischer rings are 
diagnostically helpful. Estimation of hepatic tissue copper is the gold standard for diagnosis. It is measured using 
neutron activation analysis / atomic absorption spectrometry.

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following stains can be used to demonstrate excess copper deposition in 
Wilson's disease?
questions.explanation:
944 
Sold by @itachibot Excess copper deposition in Wilson's disease is demonstrated by rhodanine stain. Microscopic findings in Wilson's disease include: • Fatty infiltration (macrovesicular) • Glycogen deposition in periportal hepatocytes • Macronodular cirrhosis in decompensated stages. Orcein stain is used to stain copper-associated proteins (eg: ceruloplasmin).

questions.question:
Question 6: A 55 yr old man is found to have hepatomegaly on physical examination. He also complains 
of dark tan despite avoiding sun exposure. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. 
This patient most likely suffers from 937 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The patient most likely suffers from hemochromatosis. In the given scenario, the liver microscopy 
image shows hepatocellular iron, which is stained blue with Perl's Prussian blue stain. Hemochromatosis is an inherited or acquired metabolic disorder caused by excessive iron 
absorption. Iron overload leads to the accumulation of iron in parenchymal organs such as the 
liver and pancreas followed by the heart, joints, and endocrine organs. The image below shows the triad of haemochromatosis. The image below is the liver microscopy image showing hepatocellular iron, stained with Perl's 
Prussian blue. 945 
Sold by @itachibot The total body iron pool ranges from 2 to 6 gm in normal adults. In hemochromatosis, total iron 
accumulation may exceed 50 gm, more than one-third of which accumulates in the liver.

questions.question:
Question 7: A patient with hereditary hemochromatosis is found to have a mutation in the HFE gene. On 
which chromosome is it located?
questions.explanation:
HFE gene is located on the short arm of chromosome 6 (6p). It is the most commonly mutated 
gene in patients with hereditary hemochromatosis. HFE encodes an HLA class I–like molecule that regulates the synthesis of hepcidin in hepatocytes. 
The most common HFE mutation is a cysteine-to-tyrosine substitution at amino acid 282 
(C282Y).

questions.question:
Question 8: A 34-year-old man evaluated for chronic abdominal pain is found to have hepatomegaly and 
serum ferritin level of 1800 micro g/l. Which of the following complications is he at the 
greatest risk of developing?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hemochromatosis. A patient with hemochromatosis is 
at risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma. Hepatocellular carcinoma is a significant cause of death in hemochromatosis. The risk is much 
greater than in the general population. The disease progression of hemochromatosis is as shown below: 946 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is true regarding hemochromatosis?
questions.explanation:
Neonatal hemochromatosis is not an inherited disease. It is a disease of unknown origin 
manifested by severe liver disease and extrahepatic hemosiderin deposition. It might be related to 
maternal alloimmune injury to the fetal liver. Adult hemochromatosis is generally a milder disease than the juvenile form. With treatment, life 
expectancy is normal. Bantu siderosis or African iron overload is due to dietary iron overload. Consumption of beer 
prepared in iron pots or drums is the cause of dietary iron overload. Skin pigmentation in hemochromatosis mostly results from increased melanin synthesis. This 
is due to iron deposition and not hemosiderin deposition. In severe hemochromatosis, total iron accumulation may exceed 50 gm. More than one-third of 
this accumulates in the liver. In normal adults, it is in the range of 2 to 6 gms.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following organs does not show hemosiderin deposits in hemochromatosis?
questions.explanation:
The testes do not show hemosiderin deposits in hemochromatosis. Hypogonadism in hemochromatosis is not due to the deposition of iron in the testis. It is due to a 
derangement in the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. This results in decreased gonadotrophins and 
testosterone levels. The testis will appear small and atrophic. Deposition of hemosiderin is seen in the following organs in the decreasing order of severity: • Liver • Pancreas • Myocardium 947 
Sold by @itachibot • Pituitary gland • Adrenal gland • Thyroid • Parathyroid gland • Joints • Skin

questions.question:
Question 11: A 35-year-old male patient with emphysema was found to have elevated liver transaminases. 
His liver biopsy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? 939 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
In the given clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. The liver 
biopsy image shows periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant round-to-oval 
cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes. These are characteristic of alpha-1 antitrypsin 
deficiency. It is an autosomal-recessive disorder of protein misfolding that results in impaired secretion of 1 
antitrypsin into the serum. 1AT deficiency results in excessive degradation of alveoli by 
neutrophil elastase causing panacinar emphysema. It also causes liver disease as a consequence of 
an abnormal accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes. Cutaneous necrotizing 
panniculitis also occurs in a minor subset of patients. Hepatocellular carcinoma develops in 2% to 
3% of cases. The image given is a photomicrograph of a liver biopsy from a patient with alpha-1 antitrypsin 
deficiency. The PAS with diastase stain shows the diastase-resistant pink globules that are 
characteristic of this disease.

questions.question: Question 12: On which chromosome is the gene for alpha-1 antitrypsin present?
questions.explanation:
948 
Sold by @itachibot The gene for alpha-1 antitrypsin is located on the long arm of chromosome 14. Alpha-1 antitrypsin 
is a plasma glycoprotein synthesized predominantly by hepatocytes. For 1-antitrypsin genes, the general notation is “Pi” for “protease inhibitor." An alphabetic letter 
is given for the position on the isoelectric gel. This gene has different alleles that produce different amounts of alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT). • M allele - normal levels of the AAT protein • S allele - moderately low levels • Z allele - very low levels The alleles are expressed in a codominant manner.

questions.question:
Question 13: What is the most common clinically significant mutation causing alpha-1 antitrypsin 
deficiency?
questions.explanation:
The most common clinically significant mutation causing 1-antitrypsin deficiency is 
PiZ. Homozygous individuals, with PiZZ, have only 10% of normal circulating 1-antitrypsin. So, 
they are at high risk of developing clinical disease. PiMM is the most common genotype seen in normal individuals, present in about 90% of 
individuals. PiS variant is clinically asymptomatic. Pi-null is a rare variant with no detectable serum alpha-1 antitrypsin.

questions.question:
Question 14: An 11-year-old girl with persistently elevated serum aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and 
alanine aminotransferase (ALT) has been diagnosed with autoimmune hepatitis. Which of the 
following pathological features would you not expect in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Bile duct injury and granulomas are uncommon in autoimmune hepatitis except in case of overlap 
with primary biliary cirrhosis. Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) is characterised by extensive inflammation, fibrosis and ultimately 
cirrhosis. The pathologic features include: • Emperipolesis - Lymphocytes and plasma cells within the cytoplasm of hepatocytes. • Interface hepatitis or piecemeal necrosis. • Rosette formation due to necrosis of groups of hepatocytes and resultant regeneration. The image given below shows autoimmune hepatitis with lymphoplasmacytic interface hepatitis. 949 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 15: 940 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following statements is false with regard to autoimmune hepatitis?

options.a: Type 2 autoimmune hepatitis shows antinuclear antibodies (ANA).
options.c: It can progress to liver failure.
options.d: Inflammatory infiltrate is predominantly composed of plasma cells.

questions.explanation:
Type 2 autoimmune hepatitis shows anti-liver kidney microsomal autoantibodies (anti-LKM1) and 
anti–liver cytosol-1 (ACL-1) antibodies not ANA. Type 1 autoimmune hepatitis shows anti-nuclear (ANA), anti-smooth muscle antibodies (ASMA) 
and anti–soluble liver antigen / liver pancreas antigen (anti-SLA/LP) antibodies. It less commonly 
shows anti-mitochondrial (AMA) antibodies. Autoimmune hepatitis is a chronic disorder characterized by continuing hepatocellular necrosis 
and inflammation. It can progress to cirrhosis and liver failure. Histocompatibility haplotypes such as HLA-B1, HLA-B8, HLA-DR3, and HLA-DR4 are common 
in patients with autoimmune hepatitis. 950 
Sold by @itachibot Histopathological features include: • Plasma cell predominance in inflammatory infiltrates • Extensive interface hepatitis (piecemeal necrosis) • Hepatocyte rosettes The image given below shows autoimmune hepatitis showing characteristic lymphoplasmacytic 
infiltrate and interface hepatitis.

Question 16: Which of the following antibodies would you not expect to see in a patient with autoimmune 
hepatitis?
questions.explanation:
Anti-TIF1 antibodies are not associated with autoimmune hepatitis. Anti-TIF1 antibodies are

Question 18: The histopathological findings obtained after a liver biopsy is given below. What would be the 
most probable diagnosis? 941

questions.explanation:
Onion-skin fibrosis is seen in primary sclerosing cholangitis. The smaller ducts in primary sclerosing cholangitis show a striking circumferential “onion skin” 
fibrosis around an increasingly atrophic duct lumen. This eventually leads to the obliteration by a 
“tombstone” scar. The image shows primary sclerosing cholangitis. There is a degenerating bile duct that is

Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following is not a feature of primary sclerosing cholangitis?
questions.explanation:
Primary sclerosing cholangitis is characterized by inflammation and obliterative fibrosis of 
intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts. There is dilation of preserved segments. On histopathologic examination, large ducts show acute neutrophilic inflammation of the 
epithelium. The inflamed areas develop strictures. Small ducts show onion-skin fibrosis around 
the atrophic duct lumen. There is an obliteration of ducts by a tombstone scar.

questions.question:
Question 20: Primary biliary cholangitis is most commonly associated with which of the following 
conditions?
questions.explanation:
Primary biliary cholangitis is most commonly associated with Sjogren's syndrome. Other 
associated conditions are: • Thyroiditis • Scleroderma • Rheumatoid arthritis • Raynaud phenomenon • Celiac disease PBC is an autoimmune disease. It is characterized by nonsuppurative, inflammatory destruction 
of small and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts. Large intrahepatic ducts and the extrahepatic 
biliary tree are not involved. It is a disease of middle-aged women, with a female predominance of 
9:1. Antimitochondrial antibodies are the most characteristic laboratory finding in PBC. Histopathologic examination shows diagnostic florid duct lesions. These are lymphoplasmacytic 
infiltrates with or without granulomas centred around the bile duct. They also show 
Mallory–Denk bodies. 952
